80486379.review: Эта игра уже не просто игра. Это классика. Это такой элемент русской культуры, который занял достойное место в ряду других великих произведений. Это бесконечный источник датфила. Это то, что либо даст вам невероятный заряд вдохновения и желания жить, либо отправит в глубокую меланхолию граничащую с депрессией. Или сделает это одновременно. В неё невозможно не влюбиться. В этой игре вы обязательно найдете свою вайфу, как нашли миллионы хикканов по всему СНГ и за его пределами, как это сделал я (Слава Славе!). Эту игру сложно описать словами, в неё нужно поиграть, её нужно прочитать. Она вышла далеко за пределы простой поделки группы скучающих анонов с двача. Эта игра создала свою собственную вселенную для миллионов людей. И в этом её величие.

79185167.review: Fantastic story, like little puzzle pieces that come together with each route. All the characters are interesting and enjoyable, there's really nothing to complain about. My only concern before playing was that I wasn't sure I liked the animation style, it seemed... unpolished maybe? But I was happy to find that when actually playing the game, it's quite charming and I liked it a lot. My favourite thing about this is that it's simultaneously lighthearted and intense, wholesome in some parts, horrifying in others, depending on where you are in the story. So much to discover! I think fans of Doki Doki Literature Club will enjoy this, they're different in many ways, yet very similar in others, with the same sense of satisfaction upon 100% completion. Completely recommend!

78450355.review:
Aun me pregunto por que esta VN sigue estandp gratis, lo cual no lo veo malo simplemente me parece curioso, pero de todas formas esto hace que sea incluso aun mejor, tienes la oportunidad de probarlo si aun no lo has hecho. Algo a mencionar es que fue creado por una desarrolladora rusa lo cual influye en que dentro de la trama de la VN tomas lugar ambientado en la rusia moderna, aun que para meter un mejor contexto inicias la historia asi hasta que eres transportado repentinamente a un campamento de verano que tiene lugar durante la existencia de la union sovietica en algun punto de la decada de los años 1980, en una version joven del protagonista a los 17 años. (Para ser honesto no se si esto califica como un isekai ya que el concepto y la manera en que lo llevan es similar, no obstante sigues en tu mundo asi que simplemente eres transportado en el tiempo a una epoca diferente). Ademas de que la VN cuenta con multiples finales (De los cuales me faltan por descubrir)
dependiendo de tus elecciones tu decides que hacer aqui, si solamente deseas buscar respuestas y una explicacion al como llegaste a este lugar o si en lugar de eso durante tu estadia quieres relacionarte de manera amorosa con alguna de las chicas con las cuales tienes contacto. Realmente el hecho de estar en una epoca de antaño me da una sensacion de nostalgia, en el sentido de que te sientes parte de lo que el protagonista siente y vive lo cual es un punto a favor de la inmersion que te ofrece, dependiendo del rumbo que quieras avanzar en la historia vives varias aventuras y momentos de suspenso, tension, desamor y reconciliacion, etc. Asi que depende de ti como acabe este viaje, con momentos buenos y malos. (Personalmente yo consegui el final bueno de Alisa y debo decir que fue bastante emotiva la manera en que acaba).
Como ya eh dicho la historia tiene sus momentos asi que no te vas a quedar insatisfecho con ella, tienes 13 finales distintos y horas de rejugabilidad. Otros detalles a mencionar es que tiene un soudtrack bueno y algunas transiciones y escenarios estan detallados que llegan a ser bastante bonitos.
En cuanto al contenido +18 que originalmente estaba en el juego tiene sentido y razones de estar si se lo instalas y de alguna cierta manera contribuye mejor a la historia. Pero tampoco te saca de la inmersion con fan service sin sentido. si quieres una historia tal cual como originalmente estaba diseñanada, adelante crack eres libre.
Una VN que siendo gratis recomiendo para jugar y darle un intento. no se arrepentiran.

78241416.review:
I thought: that'll be a cute little game, not anything deep. 
I was wrong.
I played it, managed (only with a walkthrough) to get a real good ending. Then I thought: okay, that's it. The other endings will be similar. Different hair color, but otherwise the same.
I was wrong again.
Indeed, it looks like every good ending is entirely different and contributes to solving the overall mystery. - Really nice concept!
The game is also fairly long, with an involved story and interesting characters. The backgrounds are beautiful and the sprites are mostly nice, too.
The sometimes overdoing "fan service" and the CGs that are a bit wacky are the only downsides I see.
If you like anime or a mysterious story with interesting characters and some romance, that's something for you!
Enjoy!

77951866.review:
Sometimes, a dream is just that: a dream.

You don't have to Google for a meaning or interpretation, as if it were a question with any kind of meaningful answer.  You don't have to assume that it is a sign, or a prophecy, or a prediction, or a warning.  Sometimes, a dream is just a dream, nothing more than a hint of an idea, sketched by your meandering thoughts, and painted by your own imagination.

Do you mourn a hallucination when it passes?  Do you grieve for your dreams when they inevitably end?  Do you long for the colors and shapes and sensations that you experienced, once the experience is over, even if you are entirely sure they weren't real?  Transient images and shadows slip away, that you cannot grasp, even if you could reach them.

Can you truly believe in something that never existed?  Belief alone does not make something real.  No matter how vividly recollected, or idyllic, or plausible that it may seem, a belief is nothing more than a wish with a sprinkling of determination that it must be real.  A billion believers in something does not make it any more real than a single soul.

But now, that belief is an itch.  You want what you 'had', you need it, the absence of it consumes your thoughts and your spirit.  You see a sound in the corners of your eye, you hear a color just on the edge of your sensory range, the spectre haunts your every waking hour, rather than the sleeping hours.

So, you try to recreate the conditions in which it occurred.  You climb aboard that same bus, sit in that same seat, close your eyes, and believe.  What's wrong with that?  Futile as it may be, there is no harm in belief itself.  But that isn't enough, thankfully.  If everything were to come to you so easily, you probably won't value it much.  So the unattainable, or that which was had and lost, is that much more precious, isn't it?

But why mourn?  Why cry?  What will it change?  It wasn't real, and it never was.  The world itself is real, but not because we believe that it is.  Reality is what we can hear, feel, touch, see... isn't it?

Belief does not work magic.  It can't conjure a presence, or a circumstance, or a place or time.  But sometimes, those presences, and circumstances, and places and times, they can find us instead.  Serendipity, happenstance, fate, destiny, these are all concepts that our inner selves use to explain an effect that we didn't cause.

There's no logical reason why the stuff of our dreams can manifest in natural reality, but sometimes it does.  It may be subtle, or faint, or fleeting, to the point that we may miss it entirely.  But if we see it, and grasp it, we can experience that which we previously only imagined.  The not-real can become real, and though belief has nothing to do with it, you may have difficulty admitting it, in that moment.  And that is what keeps the belief going, that potential, the possibility, of having your hopes fulfilled, and your beliefs realized.

...

The game's protagonist, Semyon, is a loser.  He has no job, no prospects, no action or dynamism in his life.  The game tells this story, of an internet troll, a loser from Russia, with nothing to live for, who is given the opportunity to find that reason.

Can you separate a story from the context in which it is produced?  Can a world unrelatable to many, be made to stand on its own?  Can it be made believable?  Everything can be interpreted from multiple angles, especially when you have a particular motivation.  If you hate internet trolls, you will have a bias that will need to be overcome in order to relate to the character.  If the context is too relatable to your own life, you may find yourself in the same boat, grabbing at a dream or fantasy, angrily and desperately clawing for your own serendipity or good fortune to have it made manifest.   

Depending on the ending you get in the game, he may never reach his own potential, or he may wind up happier than he ever thought possible.  Contentment and happiness don't correlate with success and prosperity.  Sure, its easier to cry in a Cadillac than a Lada, but crying is crying.

Having a dream fulfilled, even in some small way, can mend wounds and soothe the soul.  It doesn't matter what a loser you were before, or how your life trajectory was headed, or anything else.  When you reach what you've desired, fantastical that it may be, in that moment, you are happy.  You, and that which you sought, have each other.  Semyon has the opportunity to have his dreams be made real.  In that moment, he is happy.  He, and that which he sought, have each other.

Not everyone will reach their potential.  Most don't, in fact.  Fewer still are happy.  But you don't have to be the absolute best version of yourself to be happy.  Maybe, instead, the happiest version is the best one.

77682601.review:
Woah.

Just finished my first playthrough, which takes about five hours, depending on your reading speed. Certainly not what I was expecting. Interesting setting and a story that starts a bit slow but goes quite deep indeed, providing more and more questions every time you think you have figured something out. Background art is great at worst and stunning at best, character sprites and CGI look good overall although there are some inconsistencies quality-wise.

The first ending I got was Lena's bad ending, which was surprising in more ways than one. It is actually the first time I've gotten a bad ending on my first playthrough in any VN, so I guess the routes are a bit more unpredictable than in some other VNs. I thought I was making the good choices and heading for the good ending. The ending itself was unpredictable as well. I did not even realize it was the bad ending until... well, not to give any spoilers - until it was suddenly very, VERY obvious. Be prepared to be surprised.

Definitely will be going back for a second playthrough. And third. And sixth, probably. This game is free. GET IT. You will not regret it. Well, unless you are like me, typing this review at 4:30 AM even though you were supposed to go to bed early, but could not 'cause you just HAD to know what would happen next in the story. Dammit.

Still... worth it.

[h1]So first off just wanna let you all know that I don't usually play these types of games and if I do it's very rare.[/h1]

Despite this I can say that this game is a true masterpiece, the game was originally in Russian and translated  to English and various other languages. The translation (at least the English one) is really good. The story is vast and can be expanded on even more with mods! Although since the game is originally Russian it can be hard to find some English mods.  The art style of this game makes you feel all warm and cosy inside, it's just one of those games you know? There is a wide variety of girls to choose from and 2 endings for each main character, there are also secret endings!

I'm pretty sure the game has stopped being updated since it's 6 years old now and the developers are working on new Visual Novels but they still listen to their fans feedback.

[b]Overall[/b] great game with a great story and a wide variety of outcomes and decisions to be made!

[spoiler][i]Alisa / Alice is best girl[/i][/spoiler]

75262841.review:
Ok so, I like this game's premise, and the characters are all likable and cute in their own way and I really wanted to get more out of them, but the protagonist is the issue. A lot of the time the game will make decisions for you, or ignore the ones you make, and he is so annoying sometimes and outright completely rude to the girls it sorta ruins it. Like if it was up to you if thats how you wanna play, thats fine, whatever, but it should be up to the player. I felt railroaded quite a lot during the course of the game.
For positives, the story is interesting, the setting is very unique, the characters designs are all pretty nice (I like that one of them is just Hatsune Miku lmao) and the art is appealing and well done. The music is pretty good, and its got some nice horror-lite elements towards the end. 
I will probably play it again, but I entered this game with high hopes, based on its user score, and left slightly deflated and disappointed. I'll update when I've played through it a couple more times.

Only little minus point is for the character art, which is sometimes not consistent. After I finished the game, I was a little depressed for two days. I think that just proved, how good the game was for me. In a few years I will definitely come back to this russian summer camp.

72548581.review:
“And now summer has left
as if it never came at all.
It’s warm still where the sun falls.
But it’s not enough.”
                              Arseni Tarkovsky 

Everlasting Summer is a Russian visual novel in anime style. We play as a modern Russian young man who lives a lonely life in a large Russian city. Someday he accidentally finds himself in a pioneer summer camp somewhere in the Soviet Union.  What happened and how to come back? To answer this question you have to get involved in the routine life of the camp and know the local pioneers. The outcome of that situation depends on you. You have to finish the game multiple times to get the “True ending”. That sounds interesting, doesn't it? And, yes, this game is free. 
Of course, Everlasting Summer is not perfect. There are many the gender and harem cliches in the game, the character designs and the background art aren't great, but I love this game because it gave me unique emotions and a sense of nostalgia for the summer camps. There are not many good Russian games, Everlasting Summer is one of them.

P. S. You have to download a patch file to get the adult content in the game.

It’s pretty much legendary VN in Russian internet, so might as well give it some more hype over at English territories. Even tho I played this game in Russian I will write my review in English. ^_^

Do you enjoy lovely stories about regular people with a romantic outcome? How about multiple endings, some of which can be sad and some quite happy? Do you like listening to lovely music while reading? How about reliving the best aspects of summer camp? Then come right here!

Don’t be discouraged with Soviet themes, it is a perfect opportunity to experience the life in a Pioner summer camp right before the fall of USSR straight from the comfort of your room. The game greets you with every day routine life of a ~25 y\o who has lost the will to search for *the* point of life and just spends his days browsing the internet. Sounds familiar? (hope not) He no longer has any hobbies, lost most of his friends, life is dull and grey somewhere in the outskirts of Megapolis (no point to specify which – they all are mostly same). But the creators, or God, or local drug dealer or *somebody* finally helps him out and sends 410 bus his way which takes him far and back in time… And that is where he, and maybe you, is reborn.
The game did something great for me – it cheered me up so well, I feel great all week since I played it. It should be given to people with depression or just people who feel let down by life. The fact that this game is FREE does not sit right with me. The music itself can’t be free! Devs are too good for us. However, as google helped me, they do have an internet store with goodies! And this year they are planning to release a new game, which won’t be f2p so might as well show some support there folks.

PS.: People who game this game a negative review – what the f is wrong with you? It’s an amazing FREE game that gives you a FREE adventure, some light reading, art to look at and heaven for your ears. Do reconsider (if you read this) to change your review. There are plenty of B2P games which are waiting for your negativity.

69949834.review:
Whether I recommend it or not depends highly on what we are talking about here. Specifically, if it's the main story, or the mods. 
The main story is very unique. In the first place, it is unique for something like this to be developed in Russia. It does not borrow too much from the things that I see frequently in anime/games/movies/series, it has it's own charm. The characters are not "OH MAH GHAD TOP TIER SHIT" but they are definitely complex. There was effort put in, whoever wrote them. This is a dating sim, yet none of these characters are two dimensional waifu material for the sake of being appealing, they are a retrospective of real people in real life. The same touches were made for the protagonist of the story, though he is far less unique and is on the whole "socially awkward and unappealing, low self esteem young man normally a cuck but now a chad" deal. That's my first gripe, though complaining about this is elitiesm - most modern anime have that thing, and it's not necessarily always bad; in this guy's case at least, he has some appeal to him - he is a good soccer player, and pretty athletic, that's something.
My second gripe, and the one that puts this product from being a masterpiece, came upon me when I completed the game. There are 13 endings, 2 for each of the four main girls (8), one good and one bad, then 1 secret one that is available after completing the game once, 2 for not dating anyone (one good one bad), the true one that is available upon completing every good ending (and a secret one), and a harem one, with the same condition. The problem is, this is simple. The mechanic behind the game is simple. Be nice to a certain girl a certain number of times, you date her. Be nice to her a bit more, you get a good end. There is a score counter (widget) hidden in the game (actually you can enable it through mods IIRC) and that alone gives you a complete grasp of the entire game - which route you fall onto and so on and on and on. All 13 endings are easily accessed. Once you did that, the game has essentially outlived itself. There is nothing for you to explore anymore. 6/10
...EXCEPT the thing that makes me recommend this game. The mods, or fanfics, or whatever you may call them. This is where the top notch content is at... is something I would like to say but of course, among a thousand fanfics, there will only be a few good ones. The good ones are the ones the most people are subbed to. And of course, most of them, if not all, are untranslated, though I do plan to work on it in the future. Here are my three favorites.
7 Days of Summer, basically everybody knows it as a retelling of the main story. The content that was added involves new characters, the old ones getting more important (one of them actually being instrumental to the greater scheme of things), a different lore explanation - like, DRASTICALLY different, the main characters being more complex and there being more than 50 endings instead of 13. And btw, Olga is now datable. And there is a Karma score alongside the normal dating points. The good parts are more endings and better characters (that includes the protag). The bad point is the unbelievably slow pacing. Some of the dialogue is also very awkward. 8/10
Samantha, a completely different story. Samantha Smith, AKA the girl who died in 1985 in a plane crash aged 13, who was also trying to establish a good relationship between USSR and USA by going to a Soviet summer camp in the real world, comes into Sovyonok and our good ol' MC, now an absolute madlad chad whom history will remember for ages, is appointed her translator - because "age of the internet in Russia is gud wiz Inggleesch". And he ALSO tries to prevent the airplane crash by convincing her about him being from another world, from XXI century where she actually died etc etc. The best part is, it is translated into English - somewhat, but translated. The comedy in this one is top notch funny; the sad moments are SAD, they hit really hard. Dialogue, although it is awkward in translation, is great. 10/10
Last Summer - the what if scenario sci fi lore expansion sequel to the main game, diving into the MC's mind deeper than the mainline game did. Pretty heavy and philosophical. Currently incomplete, but three chapters are done - in Russian, but still done. Highly recommend, 7/10

69264856.review:
16.5.2020.									Game #125

[h1] Most dating sims don’t really stand out [/h1]

Playing this game, made me realize something. I don’t think dating simulators really stand out. I have played a few dating simulators but, I barely remember any of them. I know Steam is full of them but at the same time, they don’t really stand out. I mean, most dating sims have the same format. You play as an awkward, socially-outcast guy, you have a couple of potential dates, you usually choose just one and you watch the wonderful still images as you read through tons of text. 

[h1] The only dating sims that DO stand out are the weird ones [/h1]

Unless you are really into dating sims, you probably won’t be able to name many of them. Other than Hatoful Boyfriend 
https://store.steampowered.com/app/310080/Hatoful_Boyfriend/
 or Doki Doki Literature Club
https://store.steampowered.com/app/698780/Doki_Doki_Literature_Club/
, I couldn’t really tell you a popular dating sim because they really don’t stand out. I guess, if someone wants to make a popular dating sim that will stand out outside of its community, they better make something really weird. I’m kind of sad to say that, while Everlasting Summer is unique, it doesn’t do much to really stand out among the rest of dating simulators.

[h1] A non-Japanese dating simulator? [/h1]

On the surface, Everlasting Summer, doesn’t do anything much different from other dating simulators. You have the main character who is socially awkward, you have a couple of eligible love interests that all have different personalities and looks, you mostly read loads of text and every now and then make a decision and the graphics are presented with still images. 

While most dating simulators are anime-based and thus made in Japan, this one was made in Russia, thus it takes place in Russia. Most characters look like typical anime characters, even act like them, but the game really wants to hammer in the point that it takes place in Russia. 
I just want to point out that this is really refreshing. While it’s clear that the game takes inspiration from numerous Japanese dating sims, the culture, the location, the events and the overall theme are very much Russian. 

[h1] Be prepared! Always prepared [/h1]

The story starts with out 20-something main character derping on his computer in his room. The main character is complete social outcast. He almost never leaves his home, he mostly spends time at his computer, he has no ambitions, you get it. One day, he gets on a bus and falls asleep during the trip. When he awakes, he is on a completely different bus and is in a USSR young pioneer camp. What’s worse is that, he has no idea how he got here, what year is it and why did he suddenly become a teenager again. Seeing how the camp is located in the middle of nowhere and how he has no idea how to return home, he stays at the camp as a young pioneer. 

In case you are curious, young pioneers were something similar do American boy/girl scouts. Basically between 1920s-1990s, kids aged from 8-18 (I guess) would become pioneers and would spend summers at pioneer camps. There, they would learn various skills, discipline and socialize with other pioneers. It was a way to raise healthy patriots and potential soldiers. Honestly, I think the movement was a wonderful idea and I am sad that the Young Pioneers don’t exist anymore. I would have loved to go to a camp like this back in my days, but that’s beside the point. 

[h1] If you had a chance to re-experience being a teenager again with your current mindset, what would you do differently? [/h1]

Like I mentioned above, Everlasting Summer, other than being Russian themed, doesn’t really stray at all from the regular dating simulator formula. You will lead your peaceful life in the pioneer camp and as you go through your daily routine, you will get choices that will impact the ending of the game. Depending on which girl you decide to pursue, each playthrough can be a whole new experience. 

The main character is a dweeb. I really couldn’t relate to him, no matter how hard I tried. Usually, when you play these games, you character “evolves” into your own persona but the main character was set on being the most depressive person ever. He constantly complains about everything, he is unsure of his feelings, when he has time, he always takes naps and when it’s DEAD OBVIOUS a girl likes him he doesn’t realize it and makes the whole situation awkward. I guess, he acts like a typical teenage boy but he is actually a 20-something year old, meaning, he is very much immature for his own age. 
The potential love interests are typical dating simulator girls. You have the down-to-earth one, the one that looks underage, the angry one, the quiet one, the loud one… typical stuff. Actually the loud one is Hatsune Miku, I didn’t much care for her since she really seemed out of place. 

The story itself is pretty linear and will probably play pretty much the same each playthrough and the only thing that will be different is the girl you end up with depending on your decisions. 
I really loved the Russian setting. The game takes place in around the early 80s and I loved the little cultural details that they used. You brush your teeth with tooth powder, you will eat Kompot and drink Kefir, all characters have beautiful Russian names (except for Miku) and it’s just a joy to get a glimpse of what being a pioneer was all about. 

[h1] In Soviet Russia, decisions make you [/h1]

While you do get to make a decisions about which girl you will pursue or how you will spend some days, these come really rarely. I really wished that there were more decisions to be made during my playthrough, especially during the ending. One time, my character was tasked with delivering a package and he decided to open it and temper with it. I would have just delivered the damn thing and not care at all about the contents but the game was set that way and I found it really immersion breaking. I mean, often, I wanted to choose what to do next and the game just didn’t let me. Still, I didn’t feel like the game chose right girl for me because I really wanted to end up with the angry one and, I’m happy to say that I did end up with the angry one. 

[h1] Everlasting summer really made me question the state of video games [/h1]
I played Everlasting summer for 8 hours and have only seen one ending. During these 8 hours, I had a lot of fun. Now, lately I have been playing games that lasted for 2-3 hours that wanted like 15 – 20 euros. Everlasting summer is free. There’s no catch, it’s a free game and I’ve had a lot of fun with it. Even if had a laundry list of problems, it’s hard to not recommend a free game. 

[h1] Play this game [/h1]

I’d like to end my review with this message which should summarize my feelings about Everlasting summer.

[h2] I would have paid money for this game [/h2]

Next game: Evoland Legendary Edition

Tengo algunos detalles que mencionar con spoilers. Hablemos de "Miku":

[spoiler]
Personalmente me hubiera gustado que la ruta con esa chica hubiera sido con la "verdadera" Miku y no esa actriz que cae más mal que bien (no creo que nadie se llegue a enamorar de este personaje). Esperaba que se revelara algo más de esta chica japonesa y que hubiera algo detrás de ese carácter especial.
Aún así debo halagar la originalidad de esta ruta. A destacar, yo hubiera puesto las escenas duras algo más silenciosas. Yo no sé qué problema tienen los creadores con el heavy metal. En lugar de dar miedo psicológico le da un toque de comedia y no pega mucho. Me recordaba al meme de "run".
En cambio las escenas con Lena (ya sabéis de qué hablo) sí generaban mucho miedo. El mejor terror es el miedo a lo desconocido. Si pones una escena en la que no hay música o hay la de siempre y notas que algo va mal, te paralizas de miedo (como ya hicieron en Doki Doki).
Aún así, debo decir que consiguieron que después de acabar la ruta, estuviera el resto del día en shock.

Otro detalle aunque no tan importante, las ilustraciones. Para representar los personajes "cambiados", preferiría que hubieran mantenido los sprites con los detalles necesarios para dar miedo (como han hecho con Lena y como sale en Doki Doki), en lugar de hacer ilustraciones más bien abstractas, pero bueno eso ya es al gusto de cada uno.

64158144.review:
This one is a curve ball... a visual novel with typical "dating sim" conventions including some eroge art which upon reflection carries plenty of thematic baggage and is surprisingly restrained despite its mature elements.

Characters and plot are respectively well defined and fairly original. Script and setting are superficially disappointing: the multiple realities / time loops concept appears to be a flimsy cover for completionists, the protagonists' inner monologue often coming across as irrelevant narrative exposition - maybe even voicing the authors' own existencialist ramblings. The narrative depths are well hidden - in the achievement names, in the allusions which gain meaning through repeated play, in the context of collapse of USSR. Surprises and more explicit reveals do happen, particularly in the special routes.

I don't know if it's consciously trying to allude to Solaris style SciFi or it just happens to point there due to common cultural influences. It does not matter though - it's far from being in the league of Tarkowsky nor Lem but it does live next door to subversive genre pieces like Groundhog Day or Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.

Content Warning PS: the narrative restraint is rather in the underlying themes as there are dating sim and horror tropes explicitly throughout covering self-harm, sexual assault, extreme violence and even some gore. Not 18+ only, but close enough IMO.

63197568.review:
What can I say about Everlasting Summer?
  Well, I could start by saying that, for the simple fact that this game is FREE TO PLAY, you should download and test it out on your own, but I'd prefer make a proper evaluation of the credits this visual novel have, as it well deserves it.

  Everlasting Summer was my first ever visual novel, and a fine introduction to say the least. 
 The plot exploits the Isekai traits in a ingenious way, taking in account deep introspection of our main protagonist, Semion. Deviating from the beaten path the genre usually takes and turning the piece into a fun and original production, Everlasting Summer contains it's fair share of romance, terror and even philosophy, as you wander through the many paths that lay ahead of your choices. But be wary, the end of the rainbow does not always take you to the pot of gold. Sometimes it takes you to a blood stained bathtub. Play the game without walkthroughts, and you'll eventually get the joke and regret doing so.

60881599.review:
Everlasting Summer is a mediocre VN, and i'm not sure why it received the praise it has. The setting is unique - the protagonist is a nobody in modern-day Russia, until he magically gets transported to a Young Pioneer camp in the twilight years of the USSR. There is a secret bunker, a mine, a creepy Stepford Communist building robots - it's full of all kinds of mysteries! Unfortunately, you don't get to solve any of those mysteries, you just get to romance one of a series of cookie cut VN women.

The women are as stereotyped as you'd expect, but more egregious than the stereotypical women is the completely dickish behavior of the protagonist. He is a jackass every step of the way, moping about his life and treating everyone around him like trash. Still, somehow these women fall for him and depending on your clicks at least one will get nekkid for him. There is supposed to be some kind of redemption arc where the protagonist comes out of the camp with a new purpose in life, but i don't think it really forgives him being such a terrible person throughout the game.

On the upside, the music is decent and there is plenty of fan service. It's just a shame that after the good intro the story didn't really go anywhere more interesting. Better characterization and a more compelling story could have made this game something more broadly interesting than a run of the mill eroge.

60710905.review:
When it comes to free visual novels, this is certainly one of the better ones in terms of originality and replayability. 

It is essentially structured as your typical dating-esque type visual novel where there are multiple female characters that you choose to spend time with; as well as, multiple endings focused on your success/failure with that particular character or in general. I am not someone that cares much for the somewhat sexualized visuals that associate with the characters, but rather the core of the story and writing. And Everlasting Summer does deliver in that regard.

There are no voice actors, or gameplay outside of making choices and reading the conversations that come out of it. Nonetheless, with its setting taking place in a Soviet Union summer camp and characters with drastically different personalities (some straight up unlikable...and kinda creepy), I found that I enjoyed at least one or two endings a whole lot as well as the rather meta-feel this game encompasses. The music is pretty nice and the overall style feels like a sweet rendition of the anime art style in the varying seasons of Russia.

It's free but it has additional secret characters/endings that got me motivated to finding them all reaching to about thirteen hours of gameplay which is a pretty good bargain if you ask me. A sweet little game, but nothing that really stuck with me.

59679498.review:
[h1][u] An Everlasting Summer Review: [/u][/h1]
I dedicate these words to all who is responsible of the creation of Simply this amazing visual novel done by Soviet Games. 
At first, I was skeptical about what I’d find when I started playing this Visual Novel, but as soon as the first day ended on Semyon’s week on the camp, I started to fell in love with the veil of mystery that was covering this weird twisted plot. And when I least expected it, the twist was just the beginning of many more to come in the shapes of questions to raise in my head and answers to find about what was all of this about.

[h1][u] About the Concept: [/u][/h1]
The concept of the story is marvelous and quiet original from my point of view, I really liked how they developed this intriguing ambient without going too far into the details of why things occurred the way they did, that’s one of the many eyes covered with one hand that the game was telling me to come forth and explore all the possibilities, even the most questionable ones. And I say this because from here and there I found, what I consider, some black holes in the story that maybe they didn’t reach so well with Semyon’s develop of his persona and the structure itself of the world that it is constructed (I’m referring to Masha and Yulya’s path in this case), I firstly want to apologize if I take it like this, but I see both of them mostly like a nice condiment to accompany the main dish that is Sovyonok camp and Semyon’s never ending seek for the truth at the same time that he has to fight himself in this epicly philosophic war by always remembering who he was in the past and where he is standing at the moment, what does it mean to be here, and what all in this life means… All of this at the same time that he’s stuck in the body of a 17 year old boy trying to figure out if there’s more importance on such riddle or being on time for the line-up of every morning and what the other’s think of him. 

[h1][u] I really loved this: [/u][/h1]
This Visual novel gives a soft grasp on the subject of philosophy romanticized epicly in the words of our narrator, Semyon himself. This is something that I personally made me feel way connected with the game because I do love writing similar to that. Finding the poetry in every circumstance is as beautiful as remembering an old-time melody that for some reason we carry all of our lives without fully comprehending why, but deep inside we know that everything will be fine. Maybe that’s an interesting way to summarize what this novel feel like and what Semyon went through.
I don’t like nitpicking into the negatives or the ‘lack of…’ since I feel that such thing depends on each and every person and how they interpret their own feelings and how things impact on them. So, I will be more direct with this one.

[h1][u]Graphics:[/u][/h1]
With the few people in real life that I know that have experience playing visual novels, and this one as well, they all basically had a similar argument “I like the idea of the plot, but the drawings aren’t attractive enough to keep me interested”. And yes, I personally feel this as a closed mind sentence, but like I said before, everything depends on how feelings convey into people and how much they are willing to ‘sacrifice’, if we put it that way, to find joy in the unusual things that we find in life. We also can’t leave behind the fact that most of the visual novels are indeed, based on the same essence brought by Japan: Cute Anime Girls, A constant Fanservice and just the need to advance so we can get that Spicy CG or H content straight away, I’m not generalizing but we can’t discard the fact that many people play visual novels just for those reasons. 
Either way, It’s no use trying to compare an artisanal beer against the titans of the market, because certainly the numbers will speak for themselves and that’s the truth. 
So yes, when it comes to graphics, it could be better? Possibly, even at its own you don’t need to look at the CG with much attention to find the disturbances on the drawing style, and even some feature like the colors of eyes and hairs that do not match with the sprites. In this aspect, the game isn’t exactly solid, it goes with the flow that I feel it was a collective one and all gathered together in one game. Does that make it bad? Not for me, I always considered that the message in the letter is more important than the letter itself. But when it comes to this special case, I believe that Everlasting Summer received a well-deserved credit even across the globe with its message, so having a nice letter to wrap things up would be wise in the future; being more faithful with the relationship of the concept art and the sprites and vice versa. 

[h1][u]If I could leave aside… [/u][/h1]
If I have to decline one part of the story, I’d choose the condiments that I mentioned earlier (Yulya and Masha) specially Masha’s route. I rather have it as a mod for the game than an actual route, because honestly, I was expecting something else when I found out that you had a route with Miku, and I mean Miku. But dear god, that route was one hell of a trip! And I played it at 3 A.M. so the ambient couldn’t have been more perfect for that route!
As for Yulya, the story was really entertaining and I consider her one of my top favorites, but I felt that the story took some closed turns and raw bites that went from point A to point B too quickly and when the end presented itself, it left me dumbfounded with both of her ends. I still appreciated them and left me with a big smile in my heart but the feeling of uncertain in some events was some kind of a bitter taste in my mouth.

[h1][u]Now my favorite part of this thread: [/u][/h1]
The Original Sound Track.
Wonderful, Marvelous and even Magic! Each and everyone of this sound tracks are quite outstanding, I consider this an enormous column that maintains this game on the top of the hills! 
From the very beginning the game presented some curious tunes that I found quite pleasant and not at all annoying in any sense. I even have the album on my Spotify account with my favorite ones marked already! Big thumbs up for the masterpiece of music that this game launched itself with, it is an excellent fuel for the rest of the game and its originality on every stroke of a cord, on every melody and every key pressed on the piano is sensational and I personally will never forget. If I have to compare it with other outstanding visual novels, I’ll put this OST in the same shelf than Katawa Shoujo. Both games did an excellent job by spreading the magic in every scenario and every sprite bathed with their respective feelings for every occasion, the difference would be that Katawa Shoujo takes is more to a realistic ground and  will be more than pleased to letting you know how did your decisions affected the path that you are stepping on, even if you don’t speak the English language and find yourself playing the game and just hoping that the button that you pressed was a good one, the following change on the chords and instruments can take you down as good as an arrow to the head. 
Everlasting Summer however, you can even taste the magic and the fiction on the air even before Semyon gets in the bus 410 for the very first time, the trip that you take from here goes from ‘woah this is getting crazy’ to ‘wait what just happened?’ all in all the music will be the one in charge to multiply how you feel at the very moment and will start to escalate step by step with every phrase that you encounter ahead until an end comes and the process repeats again. 

[h1][u]Finally... [/u][/h1]
Thank you once more for the deliver of this game, you have proven that a game based on a different culture than the ones we are used to when we play games of this sort, it’s not bad at all, in fact its even encouraging to seek for more.

 I wish you all the very best and My best Regards from Argentina to you.

57575658.review:
Typically when something is free you are expecting either one of the following ... Poorly made or designed, poor story, poor visuals, hidden features that require payment or just general tosh.

Everlasting Summer is none of the above, in fact if this was on sale for £10 it would be hugely worth it, this has more going for it than a lot of commercial games of this genre. 

The graphics are fantastic, the artwork is well done and of a high standard, the story is entertaining and you do not feel it drags on anywhere.... and the number of multiple endings I never once got bored playing through it trying to achieve most.

Even the "spoiler alert" horror unlock spins a new twist on what is going on, won't say anymore on that.

If you had to pay for this I would recommend it, but it's free so you really have no excuse, download and enjoy, if memory serves me you need a patch to enjoy it "fully" but what's to argue about, it's free, get it.

By the way... where do I get me a deck of them playing cards?!?!

55712784.review:
Lovely music, nice story that uses all the typical tropes for it's own twist. If you don't want to take much time use a guide or walktrough, 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1197094495


This game leaves me a good memory of the stories, the whole experience is quite nice, I will always remember.
The best about it is that it's free, it runs on SteamOS (meaning it will run on Linux machines natively)

It may be a Russian game, but the art style is Japanese anime, and it looks quite nice (they even borrowed Hatsune Miku as a "cosplayed" character!)

And... there is a sequel named Frosty Kiss?
http://store.steampowered.com/app/431540/

It is clear that the intention of the game is that you follow the story and fall in love with the character you choose as a "story path", or at least you read how your character does. 

But still there is more to the game than just a simple novel story! It has drama, suspense, romance, horror, and well yeah some erotic images (If You Know What I Mean) *patch needed* *cough* the game is +18 anyways. And even so, it seems that the patch that reveals the images is still a bit censored.

https://steamcommunity.com/app/331470/discussions/0/1694917906669453764/ 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=346601625

It is clear to me that the story is used as an enigma or riddle for the player to solve and ultimately interpret it as they want. The given choices are sometimes clear about what the player would want, but other times they are involved in a mystery aura, being unclear and having no apparent effect, as the effect and repercusion of those choices will happen much later in the story and will add up (without a guide you wouldn't know for sure how the point system for the girls routes work, in some cases you would have to experiment, save, load and retry a lot )

On a personal note, I must say that I liked taking buses and follow the whole route just to see new places I didn't know before. I was into the whole "mysterious bus" plot even before playing this game! So, it is as if the idea had been thought for this in an interesting way. 

SPOILER WARNING
This game's story contains not just suicide references, but actually in a Romeo and Juliet style turn of the events, more than one character indeed commits suicide. It's a +18 game anyways. I must say I was shocked when I got that bad ending, but well, it's part of the drama.

54859365.review:
I stumbled upon this game out of sheer chance, and I'm sure glad I did! Though the genre has always intrigued me, I'd never found a specific VN to actually try out, and I don't play games very often nowadays. However, after reading a brief description of Everlasting Summer, I was so interested that I tried it out - and it's actually free, so that was very easy to do.

I am a major sucker for themes of "nostalgia" and one day I'd actually somehow found myself on the Wikipedia page about nostalgia, even though I've read about it a million times before, and that's how I got to the page for this game. Needless to say, I found it very touching and immersive, with a really interesting story. There are many different endings, and they really make you think. I would've liked E.S. good enough if it had been as straightforward as it seems as first, but it really doesn't stay that way - there are some seriously unexpected twists and turns, and the time really flies by fast the more you explore and theorise. It's clear that the developers put a lot of effort and passion into this project, and to have it be free of charge is just amazing. I really liked the artwork, music, and also the writing. The English translation has some grammar and spelling mistakes here and there, but it's really nothing too distracting and I say that as someone who's usually hyper-aware of those sorts of things. All in all, it comes together as a great package!

My only nitpicks would be that I wish there were more frequent instances of choice-making - sometimes you find yourself wishing you could choose something different or react a different way than what Semyon decides on his own during long stretches where it's only reading. Still, the amount of different paths makes up for that and it's not a big deal. Ultimately, I found Everlasting Summer exceptional, and I will definitely retain "only the fondest memories of my time at Sovyonok"! Also I will probably keep an eye on when the current project that the Developers are working on gets released.

54162023.review:
You know Semyon, the main character, whom you would never have paid attention to. He is just an ordinary young man like thousands, even hundreds of thousands like him in any normal city. But one day something completely unusual happens to him: he sleeps on a bus in winter and wakes up ... in the middle of a hot summer. In front of him is "Sovionok", a camp of pioneers, leaving behind his previous life. To understand what has happened to him, Semyon will have to meet the locals (and maybe even find his love), find his place in the complex labyrinth of human relationships and his own problems solving the mystery of the camp. And also answer the main question: How to return? Should I go back?

Excellent visual novel that may get a little tired having too many texts, but still 100% recommended.

54029324.review:
Well, this one's an interesting piece.

Characters and narrative are interesting, but the writing doesn't do them much justice. It jumps quite inconsistently between entertaining and flat-out bad. Bad, as in, dumb. Having bad writing in a VN is a notable downside. There are also some pacing issues.

But. And that "but" is one hell of a saving grace.

Even if the packaging has a few dents and scratches, this game has something many others have lost somewhere along the way: a heart.

Here's how it works:

- The character art is okay, even though it's about as inconsistent as the writing. Some are cool and pleasing to the eye, others are only meh.
- Backgrounds are great. All sharp, and look really nice.
- The music is definitely the strongest point to be presented. Styles are varied, and do a good job of accentuating emotions, especially for touching scenes.

Add all that up, and don't force yourself to read all the text letter by letter, just let the atmosphere carry you... and you get an amazing experience.

If you were a kid in the 80s in any Eastern Block country and went to summer camps... then this game will most likely hit the mark, regardless of imperfections. Just the main menu will draw you in.

Also, it's free, so what do you have to lose by giving it a shot?


Ps.: Alisa rocks. :P

51841411.review:
It is one of the worst games I ever played and definitively the most overrated game in history.

Once I was telling my friend what a masterpiece Doki Doki Literature Club is and he asked, “Is it like Everlasting Summer?” So I wondered if there are more gems in this genre and decided to play it.

I discovered that it sucked on every level. First and most important, writing. Sometimes it was literally painful to read. I first played in English and was thinking that maybe the original version is better – but no. I later played most of it in Russian and it was in the same way awful (if not worse). Love scenes – they are just disgusting. I pity the author’s partner, if he has one.

And let me be clear: I played every story line – although I disliked this game from the middle of my first run – I was just curious if it can become any worse.

I would write a better script when I was fourteen.

Secondly, “choices”. Some decisions you get to make are random, e.g. taking a random apple from a table or not. You can rarely predict consequences of your choices, because they make no sense. And once you have made a couple of mistakes you lose a girl for good, there is no way to win her back. This is why you are most likely to get one of the Semyon endings, i.e. end up alone. However, given the language of love scenes, it is for the better.

I could probably mention other issues, but by this point you should have already realized what a piece of garbage this game is.

Disclosure: except for DDLC, I had never played a visual novel before. People say that Everlasting Summer is the best Russian visual novel. I cannot rule out that it is true, but it would mean that other Russian visual novels are absolutely worthless.

2/10

Кажется, я влюбился в Юлю, в эту милую девочку, что всё время следила за Семёном. А как было приятно осознать, что Юля останется не в сознании а наяву. I played this game (visual novel) three years ago. Here's what I remember:
I found it quite nice, with good, fleshed out characters. It's a bit unique compared to other VNs, partly due to not having Japanese creators at all. The first route I finished was about what I would expect from a romance visual novel. There were some good feels and some bad feels. Maybe I cried. However, I then stumbled upon the [spoiler]Miku[/spoiler] route, which, at the time, I regretted. It was quite disturbing and caught me off guard. Strange things started happening. Just a little at first, then escalating to extremes with time. It made me want to stop playing completely, but I kept going for some reason.
I probably had nightmares about it. In fact, that's what makes this game so memorable to me, that I could even write a review on it years afterward.

I'm not great at rating things, but I'd give it an [b]8/10[/b]. Worth checking out.

50525734.review:
Surprisingly good for a free game!

I really enjoyed the atmosphere - the summer, the mystery, the "remote location in the middle of nowhere" setting. It really managed to draw you in. It was also complemented by great background music and CG. 

The plot has its ups and downs. The beginning is really strong and it really sucks you in and makes you want to figure out the mystery, what happens next and how the story unfolds. Unfortunately there are many episodes of boring exposition and introspection as well. The  internal monologue was quite repetitive at some points. 

Some of the routes were really good and evoked really positive emotions in me and had nicely handled endings, while others were really confusing or even downright depressing. Nevertheless, overall I remained with a positive impression from the whole experience.

Gameplay-wise, unfortunately you have to replay the game several times to experience everything and to obtain the true ending. You can skip already-read dialogue which speeds up the process but at the same time it breaks the immersion. I guess that's a problem all multi-route VNs have.

Overall a great game which managed to instill some emotions in me, which is not that common for many games I play.

48517644.review:
Everlasting Summer is an interesting visual novel with fun characters, nice looking art and really good music. Like a lot of people probably I tend to get a bunch of games on steam all at one time when a sale pops up so this title spent some time languishing in my visual novels folder for a while before I got around to playing it. After finishing most of the routs I decided to have a look to see how much I paid for the game and was surprised to see that it was one of the free titles. It's a long and well made game. I would have paid for it.

One really neat thing about Everlasting Summer is all of the Soviet era imagry. I'm an american 80s kid and it was interesting to have a game from that perspective. I always thought of summer camp as something uniquely american and went to one as a kid so this game was really fascinating even before the story went off the rails.

If I had a criticism (and it's a relatively minor one) there were some translation issues I don't know if the translation got better as the game progressed or if I just got used to it but before reaching the camp the first time I was worried the game would be a bit of a slog. The story is great once it gets going though. 

One last thing, I really REALLY like the song that plays in the endings. I've got it stuck in my head at this point after playing through the whole game. Thanks for putting this title up on steam and making it available for free. I'm looking forward to the next  one.

48513987.review: how to put this game into words? it is really an indescribably awesome experience. instead of just some bullcrap self insert protagonist who is with a bunch of girls whose entire personalities can be put into a bunch of character tropes, you get a genuinely amazing experience due to the games complex mystery, interesting story and characters, and the multitutde of endings. if you play this game, i highly encourage you to get every ending, because a lot of work was put into making this game amazing. each individual ending, no matter who you go for, is a breathtaking experience in it's own but every ending culminates to the story of the true ending, which is a complete emotional roller coaster. now it's been awhile since i've played this, so take this with a grain of salt, but trust me it's a worthwhile game and all for the low low price of free. also, something i forgot to mention, the soundtrack is great like legitamately, i literally stayed on the opening screen listening to the song for like an hour while i did homework one time, it's good and it really makes the emotions hit harder when the music pairs perfectly with the scen which it often did.

To the developers of Everlasting Summer (ES): Just WOW!
To be honest, this VN is probably the the second or third VN that I have read/played.
And, I honestly cannot imagine other VN being this great. Why do I say this after only have read/played 2 or 3 VNs? Well, I am still in a great mood, peace of mind, feeling well, lively and with energy. ES has somehow awakened something inside of me that has been asleep for a long while. I've suffered (and still do, but not as severe) from depression, cronic pains, mood swings, a little bit OCD, just to name a few (though not many more anyway ;p). And, after having read/played through the VN, including the last round with Zenhya (i'm sure I spelled her name wrong, sorry :( ), I can honestly say that I am "awake". ES has not only allowed me to experience a great VN/game, it has totally rocked my very soul. Going through the different routes has allowed me to experience/feel a lot of different emotions, good and bad, happy and sad.
Don't get me wrong though, I do know that ES is a fiction VN. And I do know the difference between fantasy and reality, and I always keep my head in the reality side. I do love to keep my imagination strong, though. At my age (I ain't tellin' ;-P), having a healthy mind is very important to me. ES has delivered to me pervbial brain medicine.
Thank you, SOVIET GAMES. Thank you, very much!

48391380.review:
So, almost 4 years after my first running through this game, I’ve decided to write a small review about it. I won’t write about music, characters, plot - believe me, they are excellent here. [i]Also, there are no spoilers in this review.[/i] I will write about my emotions and thoughts that I got while playing.

It left me with mixed feelings, it’s difficult to explain, but I’ll try. With all my hatred for the Soviet Union, this game still managed to give me unforgettable memories. 
The Soviet Union is what my country and I suffer to this day(30 years after the collapse of the union, my country and I still suffering from its remnant in the form of Russia).

But as a person who was born in a post-Soviet country and lived all his childhood in the city, in every building of which one you can see the spirit of the USSR. For me, as for many, childhood was carefree, joyful and eventful. This game was able to evoke those memories and bring it back.

This game shows the Soviet Union through the eyes of a "child", in which the problems were a tasteless lunch in the canteen, being told off for bad behavior, going to an abandoned camp at night. It won't show you the [i]real[/i] Soviet Union, with repression, poverty, corruption, lack of human rights... And that's what made me feel ambivalent. The black page of the history of many countries in the game is exhibited by something beautiful, something where you want to be. But it's not. And you have to remember that while playing. 
And that's the main problem with this game. 

[h1]It is easier for people to believe in sweet lies than in bitter truth.[/h1]

48178236.review: This game was way more interesting than I initially gave it credit for. The artstyle turned me off at first, but it was rather easy to get used to. There are some really obvious character tropes, (tsundere, yandere, etc.) but the developers did a nice job of adding their own twists to classic archetypes. The characters do not at all feel one or two dimensional, and are actually likeable/dislikeable. I actually sat in my chair for a good ten minutes deciding whose route I wanted to go on. I don't typically do that for VNs. If there was one thing I had to critique, though, it would be how the endings work. Luckily, there are guides on Steam and the internet, but I feel the game is not forgiving enough in terms of making "mistakes". Sure, making choices that would negatively should cause some strife, but you're only allowed to make one wrong decision, if that. If I had to suggest a change, I would take a page out of Katawa Shoujo's book and add a neutral ending for each character. But, seeing as the studio was relatively new and unheard of (at least in the US), I can understand. Overall, Everlasting Summer was an enjoyable experience, with much more depth than is first revealed.

This game is good. I’ve played many visual novels, and this one probably has the most nice little hidden storylines and characters. The characters are very different and I often just sat there thinking about the consequences of my actions, because this game really does emphasise how small decisions can change things in a big way. There is a wide selection of female love interests to pursue, but you don’t have to stick to one of them. and even if you do, you will probably want to restart the game and try and see what happens with every single one of the characters, because all of them are intriguing, and some of them are hard to get or even portrayed to be impossible to attain, making things a challenge.

47655224.review:
While diving into visual novels, I figured I’d give Everlasting Summer a try due to the positive reviews and attractive price tag. The story is mysterious and interesting and the characters well-crafted. I enjoyed my first playthrough right up until the end, which fell a little flat for me.

The pathways to the various endings are not very clear and while not a bad thing on its own, a single wrong choice on something innocuous could prevent you from obtaining the ending you are aiming for. This leads to a certain pair of endings being the most common. In my opinion, these endings are also the least interesting and least satisfying. My second playthough resonated with me much more. The ending presented a “wow, that’s so cool” moment that I didn’t really have for my first ending, and I was excited to go back for round three.
